title: Add iGEM prefixes and suffix to lambda auto-annotate
Colors for annotations should be cached so that they do not change whenever the viewer is re-rendered
Allow viewer to export raw HTML for rendering
body: The viewer can currently render using ReactDOM or return the React component for the viewer. Returning the raw HTML for the viewer is not currently fully supported. The returned HTML should be sufficient to render a working viewer.

title: Add basic support for sbd and ape files
Turn off some of the console logging spam
body: Remove the configuration dump, selection dump, and search dumps to the console.

title: use domain specific css class names and ids
body: add la-vz- to all classnames and ids to prevent unintentional overloading and conflicts on the client side

title: Make sure the library only re-renders what changes
body: I am experiencing noticeable lag when interacting with the rendered sequence viewers. There may be a full viewer re-render for every drag-select highlight movement made. This would cause the viewers to re-render excessively and cause lag. If this is the cause, this should be resolved.

title: Only print notice about loading part from cache once per part
body:
Possibly/probably related to #13. 

I'm noticing an excessive number of duplicate console log statements when interacting with the sequence viewers after initial load of a part + backbone. This message is only useful once, if necessary at all in production. I would consider removing entirely.

title: Improve sequence selection meta labels size responsive
body: Sequence selection meta labels in the header can exceed allotted space and push into a new line creating unwanted UI problems. Handle the labels div exceeding the predefined width for their section by collapsing into a single label dropdown.

title: Add Lattice branding and Links out
body: Include a section about SeqViz being "powered by Lattice" with a Lattice brand, link to the SeqViz library repo, Documentation (if appropriate), and some contact details.

title: Add starting directions and load sample button for semantic-ui demo
Allow find highlights to be selected
body: port find highlights refactor over from Loom

title: Implement query paramenters for backbone and biobrick in semantic-demo
Enzyme cut sites should be clickable on the linear and circular viewer
Add primers to SeqViz
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Add visualizations for primers in linear and circular viewer so that constructed parts can have their primers shown

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Port over visualization code for primers from Loom

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

None

**Additional context**

Added to support Gibson Tool demo, also requested by SeqViz Survey respondent.

title: Add translations
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Translations are absent from SeqViz. Are a way to visualize translated amino acid sequences. Should be exposed via something similar to the annotations schema.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
- [x] Be able to programmatically specify a translated region through a "translations" property on input
- [ ] Be able to infer which open reading frames are large enough to automatically have translations shown (with a programmatically exposed default parameter)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Only ambiguity here is around:

1. automatic inference open reading frames that should be translated (based on length, or length as a ratio of full sequence, or whether the sequence is just a single ORF)?
2. whether we also want an ORF toggle. I put ORFs (different from translations) in Loom but that wasn't ported over either

**Additional context**
I already made this in Loom's sequence viewer, see screenshot below, but it wasn't copied over when parts of that viewer were made open-source.

![Screen Shot 2019-10-22 at 11 06 05 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13923102/67300710-652d3000-f4bc-11e9-9627-cc9028a7c9f6.png)

title: Add color-coded bp
body:
**Describe the feature you'd like added**
Nucleotides should be color-codable for differentiation.

**(Optional) Describe examples of similar features elsewhere**
Benchling's circular viewer _almost_ has this but not quite since the bp are shown are rectangles when zoomed in enough.

![Screen Shot 2019-10-22 at 11 30 07 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13923102/67302945-abd05980-f4bf-11e9-9af1-7784c469821b.png)

**Additional context**
Will likely be added as a key-value object through input. Example below. Undefined colorings will remain black.

An alternative or secondary approach would be to have bpColors accept a boolean, and use the "colors" already passed for annotations to seed the bp colors.

```js
{
    ...restOfOptions,
    bpColors: {
        A: "#ff0000",
        T: "#00ff00",
        G: "#ffa500",
        C: "#ffff00",
    }
}
```

title: Changing bpColors does not immediately re-render
body: **Describe the bug** When toggling bpColors on and off, the colors do not appear until you scroll down to view parts of the sequence that are not currently visible. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: - Create a toggle to turn bpColors on and off - When toggling, see the colors don't immediately change **Expected behavior** The colors should immediately change when toggling bpColors on and off **Screenshots** **Desktop (please complete the following information):** - OS: iOS - Browser: Chrome - Version: 78

title: Annotation end does not line up with sequence
body: **Describe the bug** When rendering seqviz with a longer sequence and annotation, the end of the annotation and sequence do not line up. **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behavior: - Replicable with the following part: ```txt annotations: Array(1) 0: color: "#80D849"  direction: "REVERSE"  end: 266  name: "Promoter"  start: 0  type: "PROMOTER" name: "pC^rbs"  seq: "tgccgatacaagaacaacagcgcgttgagcgcctgccggtgggtggccggcgccacttgcttctcggtggcgagcatggtcagaaaaccctcgacttcagcttgccccatttcgcgcggatgtcgaaacccaccaaggctgcgggccgtccacaacacaaatgccttggcccagtagacataagccttctcggtctgtaggctgtaatgcaggtagcgaacccgttcaagaaataattttgtttaactttaagaaggagatatacat" ``` **Expected behavior** The end of the sequence and the end of the annotation should line up assuming the endIndex is the same length as the sequence - 1. **Screenshots** **Desktop (please complete the following information):** - OS: iOS - Browser: Chrome - Version: 78

title: Unnecessary re-renders on selection
body:
**Describe the bug**
During a sequence selection, almost every SeqBlock in Linear is re-rendered. Only the Selection blocks/edges need to be updating. This causes a perceptable lag, particulary when translations are shown on the viewer as well.

**To Reproduce**
Add translations and start quickly making selections on linear

**Expected behavior**
Selection should be an instantaneous as the cursor movement

title: Annotation extends too far with short sequences
body: **Describe the bug** For sequences that have a length shorter than the first row, the annotation extends past the end of the sequence to the end of the row. **To Reproduce** Using part: ![Screen Shot 2019-12-06 at 2 33 43 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45974914/70350783-71cfd280-1835-11ea-86db-45a4bc102dad.png) Results in: **Expected behavior** I expect the annotation to only extend to the length of the sequence.

title: Refactor `part` input prop into `accession` and `seq`
body:
**Describe the feature you'd like added**

Rather than `part` being a catch-all for an object, accession, iGEM name, etc. might be easier if SeqViz accepts _either_ an NCBI accession/iGEM id as "accession" string prop, or each of the `part` properties independently. Example:

```jsx
<SeqViz name="plasmid_name" seq="ATGATAG" annotations={[]} />
```

OR

```jsx
<SeqViz accession="BBa_B00015" />
```

**Additional context**
This change will be breaking but will reduce a lot of defensive code and, imo, make the props' purpose more obvious, rather than having `part` which is a weird amalgum of string/id/sequence/part-object. It's doing too much imo

title: Sequences with only one annotation are not rendered correctly
body: **Describe the bug** It looks like there is an issue rendering sequences with only one annotation. Sometimes the end of the annotation does not line up with the end of the sequence. Additionally, the direction is not represented and you can no longer click on it to select the whole sequence (though perhaps that is intended) **To Reproduce** The following props were passed into the component: ```javascript { "name": "BCDRBS_alt1_BD14", "seq": "gcgaaaaatcaataaggaggcaacaagatgtgcgaaaaacatcttaatcatgcggtggagggtttctaatg", "annotations": [ { "start": 0, "end": 71, "direction": "FORWARD", "name": "RBS", "type": "RBS", "color": "#80D849" } ], "annotate": false, "searchQuery": { "query": "", "mismatch": 0 }, "translations": [], "viewer": "linear", "showComplement": true, "bpColors": { "a": "#000000", "t": "#000000", "c": "#000000", "g": "#000000" }, "zoom": { "linear": 50 }, "accession": "", "backbone": "", "colors": [], "copySeq": { "key": "", "meta": false, "ctrl": false, "shift": false, "alt": false }, "compSeq": "", "enzymes": [], "file": null, "onSearch": "onSearch()", "onSelection": "onSelection()", "searchNext": { "key": "", "meta": false, "ctrl": false, "shift": false, "alt": false }, "showAnnotations": true, "showIndex": true, "showPrimers": true } ``` **Expected behavior** I expect the end of the sequence to line up with the end of the annotation and for the direction to be represented. **Additional context** Thanks!

title: Add more Viewer level integration tests
body:
Should add more tests to ensure that the viewer renders without breaking to `viewer.test.js`.

- [x] Render with PUC, predefined part as input
- [x] Render with  iGEM part input through the accession input
- [x] Render followed by setState to update bpColors
- [x] Render without an annotations array, just seq and name
- [x] Render with window.File input:
  - [x] Genbank
  - [x] Fasta
  - [x] SBOL
  - [x] Snapgene
- [x] Render with a zoom outside the 0-100 range

title: Add a check for zero height or width
body:
SeqViz uses React SizeMe to calculate its viewer(s) heights. If the element that contains SeqViz lacks a defined height or width, there's a good change SeqViz will as well. This can be addressed by a user by either:

1. Giving an expanded height + width to the element that contains SeqViz or
2. Passing an `options.style` down to SeqViz that manually sets its height and width

I'll add a check within SeqViz that will throw a warning/error (undecided) if the height or width is detected to be zero.

title: NCBI Accession ID query fails
body:
Hi, I wanted to test your `options.accession` feature where you say you are able to populate annotations for any given NCBI accession ID. I ran the demo on my machine via `npm start` and tried to search an NCBI accession ID, but it logged a CORS error. I tried to add a `"proxy":"https://localhost:3001"` but still couldn't get it to work.

The ID I tested was `34577062` 
And the error was 

```
Access to fetch at 'https://eutils.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/eutils/efetch.fcgi?db=nuccore&id=34577062&rettype=gbwithparts&retmode=text' from origin 'http://localhost:3000' has been blocked by CORS policy: Request header field x-requested-with is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Headers in preflight response.
```

Am I missing something basic?

title: Genbank annotation parsing
body:
Hi! I was running into some trouble with annotations when giving the SeqViz component a Genbank file to read. The visualization appears correctly, but none of the annotations have the proper name parsed from the Genbank file, instead labeled as something like "CDS-648".

After doing some digging in `io/parsers/genbank.js`, I think I've found the cause of the issue. On line 189 of `io/parsers/genbank.js`, new annotations are given the default name `${type}-${start}`, however this introduces a bug later on. In line 211 of `io/parsers/genbank.js`, as part of the defensive check to see if a name isn't already defined for the annotation, it checks if `annotations[annotations.length - 1].name === "Untitled"`. This will never be true, since the default name given is something like "CDS-648", so none of the annotations ever get a proper name set.

I propose that either the default name given is "Untitled" on line 189 of `io/parsers/genbank.js`, or the condition `annotations[annotations.length - 1].name === "Untitled"` on line 211 of `io/parsers/genbank.js` is removed.

Thanks!

title: Add ability to limit the range over which enzymes are applied
body:
From https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqviz/issues/88

In other subject, is there a way to set a windows of search? for example.

```
enzymesCustom: {
          "TestEC": {
            rseq: "NGG", // recognition sequence
            fcut: 0, // cut index on FWD strand, relative to start of rseq
            rcut: 1, // cut index on REV strand, relative to start of rseq
            wsearch: [ "5:15", "20:30" ] //meaning the range for different windows searchs for NGG pattern
          },
}
```

in that way the enzymesCustom "TestEC" would displayed only between position 5 to 15 and 20 to 30 (if there is a match), no wsearch would mean search in whole sequence. Is that possible?

thanks you in advance!
Regards

title: onSelection object without name tag
body:
Hi,
I found another bug (I think). This time I have working with the onSelection option, I tried to get the name of my tag (in the example below: "test2 with long text inside"). But, the object doesn't have the `name` field, I checked for the entire object and I could not found where the tag is. Is this a bug or the name tag is in some hidden field?.
![Captura de pantalla de 2021-03-05 16-24-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15197238/110163824-586a5d00-7dcf-11eb-8378-f4febce23349.png)

I created a minimum example to reproduce the behaviour.

```
<script type="text/javascript" src="https://unpkg.com/babel-regenerator-runtime@6.5.0/runtime.js"></script>
<script src="https://unpkg.com/seqviz"></script>
<script>
  window.seqviz
    .Viewer("root", {

      seq: "TTATGTATGGCGTTGTCCTTGGAGTATTAATATTGTTCATGTGGGCA",
      annotations: [
        {start: 50, end: 70, name: "test2 with long text inside", direction: 1},
      ],
    onSelection: function(sel){
        if(sel.type=="ANNOTATION"){
            alert(sel.name); //this is undefined

        }
    },
      style: { height: "100vh", width: "90vw" },
    })
    .render();
</script>
```
I can get almost all the fields you mention in the documentation except for the name. Hope this don't give you a new headache.

thanks in advance!

Sandro

title: Unrecognized viewer setting: enzymesCustom when updating through setState
Annotation name not returned from setSelection
body:
Hello! First - thanks for building such a great tool! I'm having a lot of fun building an application around it. I have come across a small bug when clicking on a plasmid annotation. The seqviz docs explain that the object emitted following an annotation click should look like this:

`{
  // selection
  "name": ...
  "type": ... 
  "seq": ... 
  "gc": ... 
  "tm": ... 
  "start": ...
  "end": ... 
  "length": ...
  "direction": ...
  "clockwise": ...
  "color": ...
}`

however object I am capturing looks like this:

`{
clockwise: ...
element: ...
end: ...
gc: ...
length: ...
ref: ...
seq: ...
start: ...
tm: ...
type: ...
}`

I am creating my seqviz annotation objects with this shape:

`const seqVizAnnotation = {
            id: qualifiers.standard_name + makeId(1),
            start: location.intervals[0].start,
            end: location.intervals[0].end,
            direction: translateDirection(feature.strand),
            name: qualifiers.standard_name,
            color: translateColors(feature.type),
            type: feature.type
          }`

I noticed that in SeqViz repo file `src/utils/sequence.js>annotationFactory:221` that the id and color property have default values, however if I remove the id and color property from the `seqVizAnnotation` object I pass to the viewer, the viewer will not render ids, colors, or proper keys on the rendered elements. If I include the id and color, then that value is mapped to the "ref" and the viewer is fixed, but I am unable to capture the name of an annotation when I click on it. In order to hack my way around these issues I am using the id property in the `seqVizAnnotation` object for the UID of each annotation and as the "name" for an annotation that has been clicked on. 

I believe that refactoring `setSelection` in `src/SeqViz/handlers/selection.jsx:354-375` could alter the object that is actually emitted when an annotation is clicked on to match what the docs say I should be returning.

Hi JJ,
I was playing with seqViz again and I notice when you click the aminoacid, the selection wrap the whole sequence. Is there a way to select only the codon you clicked based on the aminoacid?.

if is not possible, Is there a way to set a selection? I mean, like an imaginary option called setSelection: {start: 0, end: 10} in case you want to select the first 10 nucleotides. Is there a way to trigger this kind of selection?

thanks you very much in advance,
Sandro

title: Bug report: DNA that you want to translate from start to end has a double translation
body:
To reproduce:

Tell SeqViz to visualize the following sequence in the linear viewer:  TACCAGCAG (YQQ)

Now, add this translation: [{"start":0,"end":9,"direction":1}]

Expected result
```
TACCAGCAG
Y--Q--Q--
```

Actual result:

```
TACCAGCAG
Y--Q--
Y--Q--
```

When translating the entirety of a DNA string, the tool doubles up the translation and does not translate the last element of the AA string. I think that's very counterintuitive. I think it's a bug.

title: Search algorithm broken with mismatches
body:
There's a minor, but real, bug in search.js.

For exact matches, the code uses a regex with gi -- this explicitly means one is allowed to search case-insensitively. In addition, it does not place any restrictions on the alphabet you use. It's unclear to me whether there's a secondary bug relating to the fact that I'm not sure the code is handling wildcards here.

But for mismatches, the code is absolutely handling wildcards. Unfortunately, the code also tightly restricts the algorithm to the alphabet used, and worse, it doesn't accept case-insensitive matches. The result is that if one uses all caps DNA sequences, the mismatch-allowing search returns every possible substring as a match.

This is incorrect. My plan is to fork, fix this issue, and submit it as a pull request.

Thanks for your attention!

title: React Error - Duplicate Keys
body:
When using the SeqViz React component in an app where the sequence and annotations can be changed dynamically, the SeqViz component will often cause the following error:

_"Warning: Encountered two children with the same key, `5829780135-0`. Keys should be unique so that components maintain their identity across updates. Non-unique keys may cause children to be duplicated and/or omitted — the behavior is unsupported and could change in a future version."_

The error occurs randomly but is easy to reproduce.

The rendering of annotations will be scrambled when this error occurs and it seems to be related to a corrupt component state. Reloading the page will solve the problem. I've implemented a workaround where the parent component will first render the page without the SeqViz component and after a delay of 100ms the page is rendered again with the SeqViz component to force a reset of the state.

`<script type="text/javascript" src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/regenerator-runtime@0.13.3/runtime.min.js"></script>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="https://unpkg.com/seqviz"></script>`

Without the regenerator-runtime SeqViz doesn't work directly.

title: SeqViz componentDidUpdate logic rework
body:
I have discovered an edge case that is triggered when changing the viewer state. I noticed in my application that despite sending the correct props to SeqViz, certain plasmid maps were rendering the incorrect start and stop indexes for the annotations. I found that this was due to incoming annotations using the previous plasmid's sequence length in the `parseAnnotations()` function (`SeqViz.jsx` line 138).  In the `componentDidUpdate()` hook, when the previous props are destructed, the sequence length of the previous plasmid is extracted. This value is then passed into the `parseAnnotations()`function with **the current annotations**. I believe that the **current sequence** should be used instead of the prior sequence so that an accurate calculation of the annotation start / stop index can be made.

I have cloned a local copy of seqviz and used `npm link` to generate a symlink between the local seqviz and my application. When I change line `SeqViz.jsx` line 138 from

`this.setState({ annotations: this.parseAnnotations(this.props.annotations, seq) });`

to 

`this.setState({ annotations: this.parseAnnotations(this.props.annotations, this.props.seq) });`

My plasmid maps render correctly.

title: Sequence highlighting feature request
body: Hello, As we use this sequence visualizer, we have found a few usecases where it would be very helpful to be able to show multiple custom-highlighted areas of a sequence. One of these usecases is related to restriction enzymes. While the built-in restriction enzyme feature is extremely useful, we have gotten feedback from our biologist folks that they would really like to be able to easily see just the recognition site of an enzyme in addition to the cut site. I've attached an image of what I am referring to below. ![Screen Shot 2021-09-20 at 12 15 56 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/91080861/134037081-60cfee3c-2ca4-4264-b908-5da4f987a94c.png) Another usecase for the ability to highlight areas of a sequence is in cases where we would like to show to the user certain problematic areas of a sequence, such as areas that have too low of gc content. Currently the best solution we have found to this is changing the color of the bases at those indices, but that is not very easy to see: if we were able to use something similar to the search highlighting functionality, but to highlight any arbitrary number of sections of the sequence at some given indices, we could solve both of these problems (and there would probably be other applications as well). If there is already some workaround we could use to do this, please let us know. Otherwise, we would love to see this added to the visualizer! Thank you, Luísa

title: seqviz
Visualising amino acid sequences
body: Hello! First of all, thank you for this awesome tool! I'm using the React SeqViz component to display nucleotide sequences but I would also like to display, in the same component, my own amino acid sequences instead of the translated version provided by seqviz. I tried to input my amino acid sequence in the "seq" prop but the spacing between each AA is quite irregular and specially problematic with the I's (see attached). I'm wondering if there is any easy fix for this... Perhaps a prop for custom AA sequences plus one to turn off the display of nucleotides or a boolean AA sequence prop that would adjust the spacing in case the input sequence is AA? Looking forward to hearing your feedback. Thanks, Daniel Note: I did change the CSS style of the component but I believe that is not what is causing the issue since nucleotides work fine.

title: Single location features are displayed wrong
body:
Hi,

I have a problem with single letter features. I thought it was a [problem with BioPython](https://github.com/biopython/biopython/issues/3766) but it seems the issue is here. A single location feature will be written as

```
     primer_bind     2150
```

Such a feature is then displayed by seqviz from that location until the end of the `source`, for example,

```
     source          1..12405
```

when it should indeed be a single letter long.

title: Consecutive selections of an annotation do not predictably trigger the onSelection() function.
body:
**Describe the bug**

I'm not sure if this is a bug or a feature, but I noticed that---when clicking on the same annotation---the onSelection() function was not getting executed multiple times.

This poses an issue for my use of the Sequence Viewer for the following reason:

- I have state that tracks the selected annotation
- The onSelection() function I pass to the Sequence Viewer sets that state
- I have a button that clears the selected annotation that was stored in state
- So if I select an annotation -> the onSelection gets executed as expected and sets the annotation in state -> but if I then select the button to clear the selection -> then click the same annotation again -> the onSelection() function is not getting executed (so the selection is not getting set in state)
- the work around seems to be that I need to click another annotation first before again clicking the desired annotation

**Expected behavior**

- My expectation was that the onSelection() would get executed again and the annotation would get stored as the selected annotation again.

title: Support SSR
body:
**Describe the bug**
In working on the demo's migration to Next.js, I found that we can't do SSR of the viewer because of refs to document,window,etc. see: demo/pages/index.tsx

I tracked this to our style loaders, css-loader+style-loader, transpiling in those refs. I tried but failed to replace them with isomorphic-style-loader. I think the actual fix is to use something like CSS modules everywhere like: https://nextjs.org/docs/basic-features/built-in-css-support#adding-component-level-css

**Expected behavior**
Server-side rendering of the viewer is possible

title: Bump CDN React version to v18
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**
I can't bump the lib's default react version to v18 because then the tests break and there's no testing shim for React 18.

**Describe your preferred solution. (What)**

Migrate to https://testing-library.com/docs/react-testing-library/intro/

title: Break file-parsing into a separate package
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**
Many app developers will already do file parsing (eg: upload a Genbank) within their app, and then use SeqViz simply to render it. It's a bit weird for a viewer (presentation) to also do the file parsing. It's a cool trick, but then the consumer of the app doesn't get the benefit of using the parsed annotations/name/seq etc that we took from the files.

**Describe your preferred solution. (What)**
Break all file parsing into a new pkg, "seqparse" or something lame like that. Could also be used as a CLI and be broadly useful

title: Migrate to something framework agnostic
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**

From Justin at GenomeMiner:

> it would be cool if it was written in a web component exportable way (like is possible using svelte where you can compile to a web component, and maybe some other way thats possible besides svelte ??) so that it could be used in any JS project without having to use React. I moved on from React awhile ago code in Vue or Svelte primarily so in order to use seqviz I wrap it in React runtime just to use it w/ vue/svelte.

I was also kicking around Stencil: https://github.com/ionic-team/stencil

Obviously, Vue is ascendant, and Svelte too, so I can definitely see a strong argument for this if SeqViz is meant to have longevity. We provide a thin wrapper around the React implementation right now, but there are emergent frameworks that make it easy to compile across implementations

title: Add third viewer: a one-row Linear Genome Overview
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**

This has been our most important request so far. The circular view is great because it gives an overview of the full sequence. However, it's circular, which should only represent plasmids. We would LOVE a similar linear view, similar to what Snapgene does (does really well btw).

This would also largely solve viewing much bigger sequences, such as organisms where scrolling through millions of bp is unfeasible.

- from Holger Thorup at https://invertbio.com/

title: Protein support
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**

Currently SeqViz has AA-support which nicely translates into proteins in the view, however, we have files that does not have the AA-sequence pre-translation but only the protein. And since there's no way for us to translate back to AA we cannot really use SeqViz for visualising these.

- from Holger Thorup at https://invertbio.com/

title: InvertBio seeing bugged annotations
body:
### Buggy annotations
We mostly use SeqViz with genbank files and have noticed that annotation parsing is off without us being able to really figure out why/how to fix it in the files. I can try to find an example for you we can share (hard because it's mainly customer IP we're working with). But the same file in SeqViz and in Snapgene render differently and it results in both more, but wrong, annotation shown in SeqViz and fewer/hidden annotations that doesn't appear in SeqViz.

### Visualisation of unassembled strains
Some of the genbank files we have contain multiple strains (typically unassembled reads), which SeqViz by default concatenates the sequences as it was one – which is  wrong and hard to catch. Snapgene let's you select which of the sequences to view, which is what we've now built ourselves too, so that we add a select-step before rendering just one of the sequences in the file with SeqViz.

- from Holger Thorup at https://invertbio.com/

whatever the fixes are they're go into https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqparse

Allow for custom labels in circular view
body:
- **Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**

Currently, labels from the circular view are all the same:
![imagen](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14314257/215818968-c5674769-04ca-4c54-b4e2-ccd397e19d9c.png)

Maybe add an additional prop to the AnnotationProp called `style`, which would be applied to the corresponding label in the circular view. E.g.:
```javascript
{
  "start": 1160,
  "end": 1192,
  "name": "Zinc finger - Matrin-type",
  "direction": 1,
  "style": {
    fontWeight: "bold",
    fontSize: "larger"
  }
}
```

title: Add Number Of Search Hits
body:
**Summarize your feature idea. (Why)**

I'm currently working with `seqviz` in a hobby project to practice/learn a bit and am currently dealing with the `search parameter` of the component. If you are searching for a certain sequence, it can be a bit difficult to determine the number of search hits, depending on the total number of nucleotides.

I would have expected that either directly in the component or in the metadata area, a small display regarding the search hits would be available. If it's already implemented and I just can't find it I apologize in advance.

**Describe your preferred solution. (What)**

![2023-02-01_20h11_44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/70109596/216142819-81bc8dd0-d00e-48d4-b6dc-96490dd18b71.png)

Would display something like `4 Search hits for 'ATTT'` inside the component/metadata. Another idea was to add another property to the components search parameter to control the display of this little feature:

```ts
search={{ query: 'ATTT', mismatch: 0 }}
```
to
```ts
search={{ query: 'ATTT', mismatch: 0, displaySearchHits: true }}
```

title: Some bugs with translation selection
body: **Describe the bug** When I click on an amino acid, the entire sequence from the selected amino acid to the end of the sequence gets selected. When using `viewer="both"`, this also results in a strange set of circles the same color as the selection window displayed on top of the sequence viewer. **Expected behavior** Selecting an amino acid only selects the three corresponding nucleotides. Shift-clicking a second amino acid selects every nucleotide between the current selection point and the end of the second amino acid. **Screenshots** **Your environment:** - OS: MacOS - Browser: Chrome - Version : 3.8.6

title: how to use in Vue template?
body: I really like this design. While exploring the README.md file, I came across information about Without React, but when I tried to deploy this library in my Vue 3 project, I encountered some problems. I would like to ask if there are any corresponding VUE code examples available.

title: Write-features for Seqviz
body: Right now I would like to know if would it be possible to write sequences by writing manually the base pairs, or by pasting the sequence on the view?

title: Render an SVG in an annotation
body: ## Summary of then feature idea. (Why) I want to be able to render an icon beside the name in an annotation. Some annotations cover sequences that have an identified biological function that can be represented by a symbolic graphic (e.g. SBOL visual). ## Description of the ideal solution. (What) - I can pass an SVG specification for a **icon** as a parameter to an annotation, similar to the way I pass a text string for a `name` as a parameter to an annotation. - Like name, a **icon** is an optional parameter. - If the **icon** parameter has an SVG value, SeqViz should display the designated icon to the left of the annotation name. - The icon and name combination should be centered in the annotation - If no icon is provided, the name alone should be centered in the annotation. ## Conceptual mock

title: Expand annotation style customization options
body:
## Summarize your feature idea. (Why)
Expand the customization options for annotation styles beyond just background color. Given the diverse characteristics of sequences represented by annotations, expanded customization options will make it possible for users to visually differentiate and categorize sequences with more clarity and precision.

## Desired Features:

- Borders & Outlines: Allow users to customize border color and style (dashed, dotted, solid).
- Font Customization: Introduce options for font style, size, weight, and color.
- Gradient & Pattern Backgrounds: Instead of just solid background colors, allow for gradient fills or patterned backgrounds.

## Out of scope
- Icons & Symbols: Provide the ability to attach specific icons or symbols next to or within annotations (#229).

title: Linear map view
body: ## Summary of the feature idea Introduce a linear map view. While the circular map provides a comprehensive view for circular plasmids, not all sequences or plasmids are circular. For a few other reasons including readability, there's a need to visualize even circular sequences in a linear format. ## Linear map example in Benchling

title: Introduce a Primer element
body: ## Summary of the feature idea Introduce a "primer" element. Primers are short nucleic acid sequences that play a role in PCR reactions. For users, being able to create and view primers will facilitate planning PCR reactions and plasmid assemblies. ## Details - Introduce a primer element, distinct from yet similar to an annotation. - Users should be able to interact with a primer - Users should be able to set the start and end index of the primer, the DNA sequence, the orientation (forward or reverse), and color. ## Example primer visualization

title: Add a Translation handle element
body: ## Summary of the feature idea A way to name and select an entire translation. Currently, it's only possible to select individual amino acid elements in the sequence viewer. It's possible to create/select an annotation that covers the same sequence as a translation, but the two are not connected in any way. The idea is to make a connected, full-length translation handle so the user can select an entire translation and optionally name and color the translation. ## Example of a translation element

title: Linear sequence viewer does not display full sequence
body: **Describe the bug** see title. Code: ``` const sequence = '' ``` ``` ``` **Expected behavior** Have my A at the end of the sequence. If I add some more chars, everything is displayed. **Screenshots** **Your environment:** - OS: macOS - Browser: Chrome

title: snapgene format
body: **The bug** The goal is to display a snapgene formated file in a browser. This does not appear to be working correctly. However, a genbank formatted vector of the same file works perfectly. **Expected and observed behavior** The expected behavior is to display a map and a sequence. However, the map is missing features and a title. The sequence displays, but it appears that non-DNA text also appears. **Screenshot** **The local environment:** - OS: MacOS - Browser: chrome - Version 119.0.6045.159/160 **Test code below**

title: Scroll linear view to selection passed in props
body:
**Summary of the feature idea**

When `selection` is used, it might be out of view in the linear view. Would be nice that the linear view automatically scrolls to it.

We actually have a use case for this in one of our projects where we have a list of subsequence indices, which are clickable. Clicking on them right now selects them on Seqviz, but some times they are out of view.

**Description of the ideal solution**

The linear view automatically scrolls to the selection start.

title: Cut sites display regions outside recognition sequence as if they were part of recognition sequence
body: **Describe the bug** Cut sites show three important pieces of information in the seq viz sequence - the two cut locations and the sequence that is recognized by the enzyme. In cases where the cut site extends outside the recognition sequence, the enzyme definitions in SeqViz "pad out" the recognition sequence with Ns. For example, the definition of the enzyme BbsI is: ``` bbsi: { fcut: 8, name: "BbsI", rcut: 12, rseq: "GAAGACNNNNNN", }, ``` Note that the part of the sequence that's actually recognized by the enzyme is "GAAGAC". However, because of the Ns padding the rseq in the enzyme definition, the entire range is shown inside the "recognition box" when this is rendered in SeqViz, suggesting that the characters after the "C" are part of the recognition site: We've tried custom definitions of these enzymes which exclude the N's but it seems those are included intentionally - when the cut sites fall off the edge of a sequence, it causes the component to crash. **Expected behavior** I'd expect that the "recognition rectangle" is drawn around only the part of the sequence that is recognized by the enzyme - in this case, only around GAAGAC, not GAAGACACAGGG. I'd expect this to be the case for any enzyme that's currently defined with leading or trailing N's. I know there are also some enzymes with non-N wildcards, or with Ns (or other degenerate nucleotides) in the middle of the recognition sequence. For example: ``` banii: { fcut: 5, name: "BanII", rcut: 1, rseq: "GRGCYC", }, ``` ``` bgli: { fcut: 7, name: "BglI", rcut: 4, rseq: "GCCNNNNNGGC", }, ``` I'd propose that it's reasonable not to attempt to handle these cases for the moment, and to include any degenerate nucleotides (other than N), or any interior Ns, as part of the displayed recognition sequence. **Screenshots** _Inline_ **Your environment:** Observing the same behavior across multiple browsers & OSes

title: Sometimes restriction enzyme recognition/cut site display crashes SeqViz
body:
Related to #270 

**Describe the bug**

For circular sequences, SeqViz crashes when an enzyme's combined recognition site and cut site sequence span straddles the last `SeqBlock` and first `SeqBlock`. 

This bug was reported within the context of a [related but possibly different issue](https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqviz/issues/270):
> ...when the cut sites fall off the edge of a sequence, it causes the component to crash.

**Expected behavior**

If an enzyme's recognition sequence is detected near the end of the final `SeqBlock` and some-or-all the associated cut site is offset from it such that it extends off the end of the final `SeqBlock`, then the cut site should be displayed on the first `SeqBlock`, at the top of the sequence viewer display.

**Additional context**
The reported error occurs at line [178 in elementsToRows.ts](https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqviz/blob/803fc901e81a92b452d89715d520d9f358b4ede6/src/elementsToRows.ts#L178)

title: Render cut site when it goes over the end of the sequence
body:
Mentioned in:
https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqviz/blob/803fc901e81a92b452d89715d520d9f358b4ede6/src/Linear/CutSites.tsx#L40
And in: [# 270](https://github.com/Lattice-Automation/seqviz/issues/271)

**Describe the bug**

When an enzyme's combined recognition site and cut site sequence span straddles the last SeqBlock and first SeqBlock. This feature is not implemented in Seqviz as the `TODO` in the code mentions

**Expected behavior**

If an enzyme's recognition sequence is detected near the end of the final SeqBlock and some-or-all the associated cut site is offset from it such that it extends off the end of the final SeqBlock, then the cut site should be displayed on the first SeqBlock, at the top of the sequence viewer display.

body:
I unfortunately get this "translation" annotation at the bottom of the sequence, which i don't see how i would ve enabled. 

It's pretty annoying because i can't select ranges of residues (the moment you clikc on one the whole sequence gets selected via this blue `translation` flyer). I was looking forward to using the 'linear' version of the viz...

title: Dark Mode compatibility.
body:
**Summary of the feature idea**
Most modern websites use dark mode. I couldn't find a way to overwrite the colors of text from the component. At minimum it would be nice to be able to pass a variable of colorMode = "dark" | "light".  
 
<!-- A clear and concise description of the problem statement. -->
When color mode is set to dark, text should be white. When color mode is set to light, text should be black.

**Description of the ideal solution**

<!-- A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. -->

title: Add 'id' property in onSelection event callback
body:
Can we expand the returned object in `onSuccess` callback to include the annotation 'id' if it is passed in the annotations array?

For example, I have this annotations passed:
`[{` start: 23, end: 273, name: "GFP", id: 1 `}]`

Then I expect to get this identifier in the onSelection callback:
`
{
  "id": 1
  "end": 273,
  "length": 250
  "name": "GFP",
  "start": 23,
  "type": "ANNOTATION",
}
`

title: Ticks in the linear viewer are 1 base off
body:
**Describe the bug**

<!-- What is the bug? -->
Ticks under the sequence in the linear viewer are placed under the wrong base.

For example, the tick labeled "1" is under the 1st base which is at index 0.

**Expected behavior**

<!-- What should happen instead? -->

Since everything is 0-based, the tick should either start at 0, or (better?) placed between the 1st and 2nd amino acid.

Maybe something like this:
